definitions: obtain financial gain or benefit from a business transaction or investment
derive benefit or advantage from a particular situation or action
examples: The company profited greatly from the new market expansion
Small investors rarely profit from day trading activities
She profited from her years of experience in the field
Students will profit from attending these additional workshops

definitions: write code or instructions to make a computer perform specific tasks
arrange or schedule activities or events according to a plan or system
train or condition someone to behave or respond in a predetermined way
examples: She programs complex algorithms for data analysis systems
He learned to program in Python during the bootcamp
The conference organizers programmed events throughout the entire week
They programmed the irrigation system to water at dawn
Years of training had programmed him to wake early
The marketing team programmed consumers to associate luxury with their brand

definitions: arrange or schedule activities or events according to a plan or system
plan and organize broadcast content for television or radio stations
examples: They programme cultural events throughout the summer festival
The school programmes extracurricular activities for every afternoon
The station programmes documentaries during prime viewing hours
She programmes content for the morning radio show

definitions: formally forbid something by law, rule, or other authority
make something impossible or prevent it from happening or being done
examples: The new law prohibits smoking in all public buildings
School regulations prohibit students from using phones during class
High costs prohibit many families from seeking proper healthcare
The narrow doorway prohibits wheelchair access to the building

definitions: extend outward beyond a surface or edge in physical space
estimate or forecast something based on present trends or data
display an image on a surface using light or other means
present a particular image or impression of oneself to others
examples: The balcony projects three feet from the building facade
Sharp rocks project dangerously from the cliff face
Analysts project sales will increase twenty percent next quarter
Scientists project global temperatures will rise significantly by 2050
The presentation will project graphs onto the conference room screen
The artist projects colorful patterns onto the gallery walls
She projects confidence even when feeling nervous inside
Politicians must project strength during challenging times

definitions: slip forward or down out of the normal anatomical position in the body
examples: The patient's uterus prolapsed after multiple difficult childbirths
Weakened muscles can cause organs to prolapse over time

definitions: increase rapidly in number through reproduction or replication
spread rapidly and widely in extent or influence
examples: Cancer cells proliferate uncontrollably throughout the affected tissue
Bacteria proliferate quickly in warm, moist environments
Social media platforms have proliferated across the globe rapidly
Conspiracy theories proliferate online during times of uncertainty

definitions: make something last longer or continue for an extended period of time
examples: The medication can prolong life by several months in terminal patients
Don't prolong the meeting unnecessarily with irrelevant discussions

definitions: walk in a slow, relaxed way, especially in public for display or pleasure
examples: Couples promenade along the boardwalk every summer evening
The peacock promenades through the garden showing its feathers

definitions: make a declaration or assurance that one will do something or that something will happen
give good grounds for expecting a particular outcome or development
examples: She promised to return the borrowed books by Friday
The company promised customers full refunds for defective products
Dark clouds promise rain before the afternoon ends
The young athlete promises to become a future champion

definitions: raise someone to a higher position or rank within an organization
actively support or encourage a cause, venture, or aim
publicize or advertise a product, event, or service to increase sales or attendance
examples: The board promoted her to senior vice president last month
Hard work and dedication helped promote him through the ranks
The organization promotes environmental awareness through educational programs
Teachers promote critical thinking skills in their classrooms
The company promotes its new products through social media campaigns
The band toured extensively to promote their latest album

definitions: cause or bring about an action or feeling quickly or immediately
assist someone by providing cues or reminders about what to say or do
examples: The emergency prompted immediate evacuation of the entire building
Rising prices prompted consumers to seek cheaper alternatives
The director prompts actors who forget their lines during rehearsal
The teacher prompts students with leading questions during discussions

definitions: formally announce or declare a new law or decree to make it officially valid
promote or make widely known an idea, theory, or belief system
examples: The government promulgated new regulations governing financial institutions yesterday
The king promulgated decrees that reformed the taxation system
Universities promulgate knowledge through research publications and conferences
Religious leaders promulgate their teachings through sermons and writings

definitions: make the sound of a word or letter with one's voice in speech
declare or announce something formally or officially with authority
examples: She learned to pronounce difficult French words with perfect accent
Many students struggle to pronounce technical terminology correctly
The judge pronounced the defendant guilty of all charges
The doctor pronounced him dead at the scene

definitions: test the quality or accuracy of something, especially printed material before final production
make something resistant to damage, penetration, or other undesirable effects
examples: The editor must proof all articles before they go to print
She carefully proofed the document for spelling and grammar errors
They proofed the tent fabric against water and wind damage
The manufacturer proofs all electronics against electromagnetic interference

definitions: support or hold up something with an object placed underneath or against it
support or sustain something that would otherwise fail or decline
examples: He propped the ladder against the wall before climbing
She propped her feet on the ottoman while reading
Government subsidies prop up the failing agricultural sector
Emergency loans propped the company through the financial crisis

definitions: breed specimens of a plant or animal by natural processes from parent stock
spread and promote ideas, theories, or information widely to many people
examples: Gardeners propagate roses through cuttings taken in spring
These plants propagate easily from seeds or root divisions
Social media helps propagate misinformation at unprecedented speeds
Missionaries traveled widely to propagate their religious beliefs

definitions: drive, push, or cause to move in a particular direction using force
drive or push someone or something into a particular situation or state
examples: The rocket engines propel the spacecraft into orbit
Strong winds propelled the sailboat across the harbor
Her talent propelled her to international stardom within months
Innovation propels companies ahead of their competitors

definitions: adjust or regulate something so that it has a particular relation in size, amount, or degree to something else
examples: The architect proportioned the rooms to create a harmonious living space
You must proportion the ingredients carefully for the recipe to work

definitions: put forward an idea, plan, or suggestion for consideration or discussion by others
offer marriage to someone, typically in a formal or traditional manner
examples: The committee proposed several changes to the existing policy
She proposed a new marketing strategy during the meeting
He proposed to her on their anniversary at sunset
After dating for five years, he finally proposed

definitions: make a suggestion of sexual intercourse to someone with whom one is not sexually involved
examples: The stranger inappropriately propositioned her at the conference
He was fired for propositioning his subordinates at work

definitions: institute legal proceedings against a person or organization for a criminal offense
continue with a course of action with a view to its completion
examples: The district attorney will prosecute the case next month
They decided to prosecute anyone caught violating the new law
The general prosecuted the war with renewed vigor
Scientists prosecute their research despite funding challenges

definitions: search for mineral deposits or oil in a place, especially by means of experimental drilling or excavation
examples: Mining companies prospect for gold in remote mountain regions
Geologists spent months prospecting the area for valuable minerals

definitions: succeed in material terms and become financially successful or wealthy
flourish physically, mentally, or spiritually in favorable conditions
examples: The business prospered under her innovative leadership strategies
Many tech companies prospered during the digital revolution
Children prosper in loving and supportive home environments
Desert plants prosper despite harsh environmental conditions

definitions: put one's abilities or talents to an unworthy or corrupt use for personal or financial gain
examples: The artist refused to prostitute his talent for commercial advertising
Some journalists prostitute their integrity for sensational stories

definitions: lie stretched out on the ground with one's face downward in submission or worship
reduce to extreme physical or emotional weakness, making someone unable to function
examples: Pilgrims prostrate themselves before the sacred shrine
The mourners prostrated themselves in grief at the funeral
The intense heat prostrated the marathon runners completely
Grief prostrated her for weeks after the tragedy

definitions: keep safe from harm, injury, damage, or loss through defensive action or precaution
examples: Parents instinctively protect their children from danger
Security systems protect valuable assets from theft

definitions: express an objection to or disagreement with something through words or actions
organize or participate in a public demonstration expressing strong objection to official policy
examples: She protested that the decision was unfair and discriminatory
Students protested the sudden increase in tuition fees
Thousands protested outside parliament against the proposed legislation
Workers protested by striking for three consecutive days

definitions: extend beyond or above a surface, stick out or project from something
examples: His broken bone protruded through the skin after the accident
Tree roots protrude from the eroded riverbank

definitions: demonstrate the truth or existence of something by evidence, argument, or practical demonstration
turn out to be the case or have a particular result or quality
examples: Scientists proved the hypothesis through rigorous experimental testing
The prosecution must prove guilt beyond reasonable doubt
The investment proved profitable after just six months
Her predictions proved accurate in every detail

definitions: make available for use or supply someone with something needed or wanted
stipulate in a will, law, or agreement that something should happen
examples: The company provides health insurance for all employees
Local farms provide fresh produce to nearby restaurants
The contract provides that payment is due within thirty days
The law provides for equal treatment regardless of background

definitions: supply with food, drink, or equipment, especially for a journey or military campaign
examples: The expedition team provisioned themselves for three months
Ships were provisioned before their long ocean voyages

definitions: deliberately make someone angry or annoyed through words or actions
stimulate or give rise to a reaction, emotion, or response in someone
examples: The bully constantly provoked younger students in the playground
His insulting comments were meant to provoke a fight
The article provoked widespread debate about privacy rights
The announcement provoked protests across the entire country

definitions: move around quietly and stealthily, especially in search of prey or with predatory intent
examples: The tiger prowls through the jungle searching for prey
Burglars prowled the neighborhood looking for unlocked doors

definitions: trim a tree, shrub, or bush by cutting away dead or overgrown branches
reduce the extent or quantity of something by removing unnecessary elements
examples: Gardeners prune rose bushes in early spring for better blooms
He carefully pruned the fruit trees to increase yield
The editor pruned unnecessary paragraphs from the manuscript
Companies often prune their product lines during recessions

definitions: move or open something with a lever or with great effort and force
inquire nosily or intrusively into someone's private affairs or personal matters
examples: He used a crowbar to pry open the jammed door
Workers pried the boards loose from the old flooring
Reporters constantly pry into celebrities' personal lives
Stop prying into matters that don't concern you

definitions: sing or recite psalms as part of religious worship or devotion
examples: The congregation psalms together during the evening service
Monks psalm daily as part of their spiritual practice

definitions: make something widely known to the public through various media or promotional activities
examples: The charity publicised its fundraising campaign through social media
Authors tour extensively to publicise their new books

definitions: make something widely known to the public through various media or promotional activities
examples: The company publicized its new product launch extensively
Celebrity scandals are quickly publicized by tabloid newspapers

definitions: prepare and issue a book, journal, or piece of music for public sale or distribution
make information or an announcement publicly known through various media channels
examples: The university press publishes academic books every quarter
She published her first novel at age twenty-five
The government published new guidelines for public health
Newspapers published the scandal on their front pages

definitions: form into a shallow pool of liquid on a surface
examples: Rain water puddled on the uneven pavement surface
Melted ice cream puddled on the hot sidewalk

definitions: blow out air or smoke in short bursts from the mouth
swell or become swollen with air or gas
breathe in short, quick breaths, typically from exertion
examples: He puffed smoke rings into the evening air
The dragon puffed fire at the approaching knights
The pastry puffed up beautifully in the hot oven
His cheeks puffed out when he held his breath
She puffed heavily after climbing five flights of stairs
The runners puffed as they reached the finish line

definitions: vomit or expel stomach contents forcefully through the mouth
examples: The seasick passenger puked over the ship's railing
Too much alcohol made him puke all night long

definitions: exert force to draw someone or something toward oneself or in a particular direction
attract or draw someone emotionally or have influence over their actions
damage a muscle or ligament by stretching it excessively
examples: She pulled the heavy door open with both hands
The tractor pulled the plow across the muddy field
The new shopping center pulls customers from surrounding towns
His charisma pulls audiences into his performances
He pulled a hamstring during the sprint race
Be careful not to pull your back lifting that box

definitions: crush something into a soft, wet, shapeless mass or thick liquid
examples: The machine pulps fruit into juice for commercial production
Heavy machinery pulps wood chips into paper paste

definitions: beat or throb with a strong, regular rhythm like a heartbeat
emit or modulate something in regular bursts or waves
examples: Blood pulses through the arteries with each heartbeat
The music pulsed through the crowded nightclub
The lighthouse pulses bright signals across the dark ocean
Laser beams pulse at precise intervals during treatment

definitions: force liquid, gas, or air to move somewhere using mechanical action
try persistently to extract information from someone through questioning
move something up and down or back and forth vigorously
examples: The machine pumps water from the well into storage tanks
The heart pumps blood throughout the entire body
Detectives pumped the witness for details about the crime
Reporters pumped sources for information about the scandal
She pumped her arms while running up the steep hill
He pumped the brake pedal repeatedly to stop

definitions: make a joke that exploits different possible meanings of words that sound similar
examples: Shakespeare frequently punned in his comedic plays
Dad constantly puns at the dinner table

definitions: strike with the fist, especially as an attack or in boxing
make a hole in something with a special tool or sharp object
examples: The boxer punched his opponent with a powerful right hook
She punched the bully who was harassing her friend
Workers punch holes in leather before stitching
He punched his ticket before boarding the train

definitions: make a small hole in something with a sharp point, causing damage or deflation
examples: A nail punctured the car tire on the highway
The needle punctured her skin during the blood test
